stream_context.summary: Kaze blocks-out and dresses the underground section of Course 11 (an oil-rig level), adding entrances, slides, Yoshi-coin objectives, an 8-bit pipe and visual details such as a large glass grate window.

development_findings.summary: Only two sub-areas remain unfinished in Course 11; both are in the new underground section and will host the final star and Yoshi coins.
development_findings.quote: So only two areas are missing in this level and they're gonna be for the last star and the last few Yoshi coins.

development_findings.summary: The underground area links three surface entrances through a central hub; one route is now a slide that ends near an 8-bit pipe.
development_findings.quote: One entrance here, one entrance here and one entrance here and they all connect underground… the other one is gonna be sliding down the slide and jumping into this crevice.

development_findings.summary: Yoshi-coin objectives: (1) clean an oil spill with a Koopa shell; (2) perform a slide jump into a crevice.
development_findings.quote: One Yoshi coin is going to be cleaning up another oil spot right here with a shell… the other one is gonna be sliding down the slide and jumping into this crevice.

development_findings.summary: Design pivot: a huge glass grate window will let players look from the interior out to the rig’s exterior machinery and water.
development_findings.quote: What if all of this was like the reinforced window… this is just gonna be transparent material.

development_findings.summary: Kaze prefers hard-coding behaviours and limiting special cases instead of using parameterized scripts.
development_findings.quote: I'd rather just have one parameter open like I do for 255 different behaviors I can hardcode because it is so rare that I want a special behavior like that.

development_findings.summary: Engine quirk: the word "glass" is repeatedly misspelled in RTYI source code.
development_findings.quote: Fun fact: the word glass is misspelled in the RTYI source code a bunch of times.

development_findings.summary: New enemy request: a Frizzlet variant made of oil that swims through round puddles and damages Mario; external contributor invited to model and texture it under N64 limits.
development_findings.quote: I want something like that, but made out of oil… that's a random asset I need.

development_findings.summary: Material-specific footstep sounds were added by Yoshi Milkman (wood, steel, glass, leaves, meat, metal grates).
development_findings.quote: Listen closely… surface sounds… made by Yoshi Milkman… this is the new wood, there's steel, glass, leaves…

development_findings.summary: Loading optimisation: decompression now replaces Mario 64’s original 16-frame loading delay; RTYI waits 8 frames so load times feel identical on N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: Mario 64's loading times are so fast that they put an artificial 16 frame delay… we decompress… instead of waiting 16 frames, we just wait 8.

development_findings.summary: Badub has composed Bowser 2 music and is scoring the Oil Boss; tracks exist but are not yet integrated.
development_findings.quote: Badub made a song for it… he's also making a song for the oil boss that's fit to the cutscene.

development_findings.summary: Planned video will frame engine optimisations as a way to give artists more freedom and justify the expanded art team.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna frame it as like look with all this optimization artists have so much more freedom and we brought more artists on board…

development_findings.summary: Kaze considers porting Delfino Plaza to RTYI’s engine as a technical showcase of N64 capabilities.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking of porting just Delphino Plaza over to this engine and put it on the N64 and be like look the N64 could have played Mario Sunshine.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally lowers difficulty after community feedback that earlier hacks were too hard.
context_findings.quote: When you make a romhack the criticism is always it's too difficult so I've been trying to make my games easier and easier.

context_findings.summary: He quit Twitch due to intrusive ads and is rebuilding viewership on YouTube.
context_findings.quote: I got a three minute ad break that I couldn't skip… never again, don't bother with Twitch.

context_findings.summary: YouTube channel metrics are rising; each new video outperforms the previous one.
context_findings.quote: Every video is doing better than the previous one, that's actually crazy my YouTube channel is on an upwards draft.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s ethical stance is pragmatic: acting ‘moral’ helps avoid cancellation and protects reputation.
context_findings.quote: For me, actually, it makes a lot of sense to always act moral, even if I don't believe in morality, simply because I would get cancelled.

biobak.summary: Provides texture feedback (e.g., critique of underground props) and will refine window/grate visuals.
biobak.quote: I guess that's gonna be up to Biobak but I thought it looked good.

biobak.summary: Requested to keep geometry under ~150 polygons and use full-res textures; Kaze will downscale to 64×64.
biobak.quote: The geometry of this should be around less than 150 polygons… go with a full-res texture and then let me downscale it.

badub.summary: Composed Bowser 2 theme and is writing Oil Boss music tailored to its cutscene.
badub.quote: Badub made a song for it but it's not important yet… he's also making a song for the oil boss that's like fit to the cutscene.

zeina.summary: Joins chat; Kaze references her creating new ‘monkey animations’.
zeina.quote: Hello Zeina do you mean to make some stuff just a monkey animations

key_stories.title: Finishing Course 11 Underground
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to place the last two Yoshi coins and star in the oil-rig’s underground. He brainstormed entrances, slides and a signature glass window while chatting with Biobak and viewers.
key_stories.challenge: Design a memorable yet navigable underground area that hosts remaining collectibles.
key_stories.process: Mapped three entrances, planned a shell-cleaning puzzle and a slide jump, added a large glass grate and adjusted textures and platform geometry while live-testing jumps.
key_stories.outcome: Block-out and core mechanics are in-game; texture passes and oil enemy are pending.
key_stories.key_quote: What if all of this was like the reinforced window… this is just gonna be transparent material

key_stories.title: Surface-Sound Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Previous footstep sounds felt generic. Community member Yoshi Milkman produced a complete set of material-specific samples which Kaze showcased live.
key_stories.challenge: Increase immersion without exceeding N64 audio limits.
key_stories.process: Yoshi Milkman created and optimised samples for each material; Kaze integrated them and demoed in engine.
key_stories.outcome: Distinct ASMR-like footstep feedback now exists for wood, steel, glass, leaves, meat and grates.
key_stories.key_quote: He put a lot of work into making this perfect… these are very ASMR

key_stories.title: Request for Oil-Based Enemy
key_stories.summary: Kaze realised the level lacked a unique hazard matching its oil theme.
key_stories.challenge: Need an enemy that visually fits the oil-rig and uses N64-friendly assets.
key_stories.process: He invited a freelancer in chat to model an oil variant of Frizzlet, explained polygon and texture limits, and promised to handle rigging.
key_stories.outcome: Task is open; contributor will draft the model.
key_stories.key_quote: I want something like that, but made out of oil… that's a random asset I need.

open_questions.context: Kaze plans a video claiming recent optimisations give artists ‘much more freedom’, but specifics were not detailed.
questions: What concrete engine changes were made?
How do they expand texture, polygon or memory budgets?
Which team members contributed to these optimisations?

open_questions.context: Badub is composing its theme; no visual or gameplay details were shared.
questions: What is the Oil Boss concept and mechanics?
How does its fight leverage new engine features?
What stage is its development in?

open_questions.context: An ‘8-bit pipe’ is placed in the underground, but its purpose wasn’t explained.
questions: What happens when Mario enters an 8-bit pipe?
Is it purely cosmetic or does it change gameplay?
Why was it included in this level?

open_questions.context: Kaze mused about porting Delfino Plaza to showcase engine power.
questions: Is this a serious side project or a marketing demo?
What technical hurdles would need solving for N64 hardware?
Could assets be reused for RTYI levels?
